It wasn’t easy, but two things have really helped me deal with a lack of human touch and intimacy, and I don’t think they are just palliative coping:
1) internalizing the fact that I *could* theoretically, put a lot of effort into becoming a different, more attractive person, but that for me and my nature—which I value in itself—the possible but unnecessary reward (women) is not worth the guaranteed effort.

- Passionate about something.
- Has some ambitions beyond getting his dick wet.
- Has reasonable social skills and friends.
- Not jealous or controlling.
- Not violent.
- Not prone to severe mood swings.
- Not morbidly obese.
- Not a bodybuilder.

If you can manage all of that lot, I'm probably interested in getting to know you, and would probably find you attractive. Obviously the two of us might or might not be compatible in lots of other ways, but that's a very good start.

posts.sub: How do I act/behave on a date?
posts.com: It's a casual sort of thing. Give me as much advice as possible/as you are willing to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28350442
Eye contact 80% of the time
No edgy jokes
Be a good listener, try to remember the little details they can be useful later and make you more trustworthy
Try not to talk too much about yourself, you should use your experiences/stories as a way to make your date share about themselves.
Don't project too much, things most likely won't go the way you planned them in your head and that can make you choke/stutter, live in the moment.
Don't be afraid to lightly and jokingly tease them around the middle/later part of the date.
Don't be too pressed, take it easy and slow, if you go too fast they might get creeped.
That's honestly all I could think about, but the best advice is to just enjoy yourself.

Onset, location, duration, character, association, relieving/intensity factors, time

>Should I settle for him?
You're not obligated to stay with anyone you don't want to. If you're looking for a lasting relationship, there are of course better or worse things to do, but who you choose to be with and what you expect from a guy are entirely up to you.
Assuming that you are looking for something long-term, though, I think it would be useful to make a distinction between "not attractive" (as in, very plain looking) and "actively repulsive". Having a noticeable attractive partner is great, and there's no shame in thinking it's important to you, but over the long term, everyone gets uglier with age, so as long as you aren't grossed out or repelled by someone's looks, how much you like who they are as people is generally more important, because that's what lasts.

The probability of inceldom grows asymptotically closer to 100% with the number of rejection, but it never reaches 100%.
It's like p(incel) = 1- exp( - I * N )
Where I is the Incel factor and N is the number of rejections.
You gotta choose an arbitrary cut-off. For example, you hit 99.9% chances of inceldom for N = - ln( 0.001 ) / I
Now the worldwide average value for I is around 0.1, meaning 99.9% inceldom corresponds to roughly 69 rejections.
On the other hand, it was shown in literarure [Poole et al., 2003] that the average I value for 4chan posters is closer to 1.5 meaning it would probably only take between 4 and 5 rejections for you.
Hope this helped.

Yes. It was also really fucking rude of them to promise they'll get back to you by EOD and only send you the job offer after the weekend. That's life.

>Is it even allowed

>>28350205
Gather as much information as possible about the person first. Strengths, weaknesses, likes, dislikes, goals, dark secrets, everything. Then think about the person from every possible angle, every possible future you could have with that person, weigh every probability of what the next 1, 5, 50 years will have in store for you if you bind yourself to this person. This process can take a while, give it at least a month of nonstop analysis. At the end of it, just go with your gut, it will be the aggregate of all your emotions and thoughts about that person bundled into a single "yes/no" decision. If you aren't willing to put in this much effort then don't settle down, you aren't ready.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28352659
It's normal and nothing to really worry about.
Get into the habit of doing reality checks to find out whether or not it really is a dream. The easiest one is blocking your nose with your fingers while closing your mouth and trying to breathe. Other ones are pushing your fingers through the palm of your hand or checking gravity by jumping up. Choose any method and try and do it a few times throughout your day, enough for you to remember to do it when dreaming. Before doing them, always ask yourself "am I dreaming?". Funny enough, this will also help you get into lucid dreaming if thats something you're interested in

Do you get off at the same station? If so, I'd start by trying to throw in a parting word just to establish casual contact, rather than talk during the trip itself. That way there's not a risk of her feeling trapped, and you don't have to spent the whole trip silently wanting to kill yourself if it goes badly. Unless it's a really short ride or something.
But the trick is just establishing baseline contact and then backing off, encouraging her to come to you, so she doens't feel smothered. So establish a little contact, and if it goes well, just give her a casual smile and nod next time you see her and see if she reciprocates. If she's not as or more enthusiastic as you, leave it at that and don't try to start a conversation, so she knows you respect her space and she doesn't have to worry about you making her train trips awkward.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28355500
>Femanons is a copper IUD good enough birth control for you and your bf?
As with any form of contraception, it works well for some people, but not for others. It can cause heavier periods; and especially in the first few months you can get cramping; there's also a slightly elevated risk of ectopic pregnancy, but not nearly as bad as it was a few decades ago. I find it makes my periods longer, but lighter - I now get six or seven days of light bleeding where I used to get two days quite heavy and two or three days light. But they're very reliable, and don't have any of the side effects of hormonal BC. Works for me; might not work for you.

I should also say that having it put in is really quite uncomfortable. I'd say uncomfortable rather than painful, but very uncomfortable! It's over pretty quickly, though, and then you're covered for the next five years

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28355598
>Is it irreversible?
Unlike most other organs, the liver is capable of regenerating damage if you stop drinking in time. But the longer you keep drinking, the more liver cells will be destroyed, and the harder it will be for the other cells to survive, because they're doing the work of the cells you've already killed on top of their own.

So making some educated guesses about how old you are and how long you've been drinking, if you stop now, there is probably a good chance your liver will recover completely. The longer you leave it, the more likely it is that it won't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28352429
If someone is absolutely stuck at rock bottom with no connections or attachments and can't mentally move forward with their life, sure maybe therapy is needed. But the vast VAST majority of people in therapy have friends or family, maybe these relationships are not perfect a lot of the time but there are many people who could at least try to talk to someone they are close to that instead seek the aid of "a professional" when that pro is no better equipped to solve your problems than somebody that simply *cares* about you. Something like 40 million people got therapy or counseling in 2021, this is a massive waste of resources when most of these people could just try a little introspection and then bring their thoughts to someone else for an outside opinion. I liken it to going to see a doctor when you have a cold or a flu, instead of thinking "gee I feel fucking awful, maybe I need to get more sleep or drink water or eat more fruits and veggies." Most people with mental health issues are not the psychological equivalent of a cancer patient.

I may come off strongly on this but I have witnessed firsthand with people close to me who get sucked into the psychiatric system and get convinced that it's something they should continue for their own benefit. SSRIs and anxiety meds get freely prescribed and doctors rarely say "hey it's been a while, are you ready to come off of them yet?" It's just blanket treatments to keep you as a paying customer, which is why unless you REALLY need to be a paying customer for serious services, you are better off doing a DIY job at home.

Not that anon, but I'm 27 and in a similar situation as you. I only work about 5hrs a week and earn more than most of my friends combined. I have too much free time, whereas they don't. I've started going out solo to bars and clubs during the weekend and have had great success. I usually drink some vodka at home before heading out to call my nerves, and once I get to the bar/club (much easier in a bar to converse), I usually sit in a table and scope out the area. Once I finish my first drink, I approach the bar and make conversation with the bartender (can be literally about anything, this is to make it seem like you're friendly to the people around you, smile when you can and throw in a couple laughs here and there). Once I get my drink, if there's anyone near me I find attractive/approachable, I do the same thing. I just go up to them and compliment their looks, ask their opinion on something random, or just ask if I can join them and offer to pay for a round (surprisingly, this will oftentimes get you drinks paid for by them). You just have to get out there and do something. Staying couped up in your place nets you a zero percent chance of talking to someone and getting laid. At least when you step out and go to one of these places, that chance is now >0%. On days where I just wanted to wind down and sip on drinks, both women and men have come up to me and started a conversation. By simply putting yourself out there, your chances of interaction will never be 0%.

Only reason I said to focus on the interaction was simply because a lot of guys try too hard to get laid and it puts pressure on themselves, and the other person and it often ends up in a stale/forced interaction. If you're comfortable with the other person and them with you, just make a move. At worst, she'll say no she's not interested. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28352695
Some debt is more difficult to get out of than others.

Student loans and any other “welfare” loans are easy to get out of as long as you have a job and make payments.

Predatory loans are very difficult to get out of. Don’t ever buy a car and finance it from a buy-here-pay-here car lot. They purposefully charge you interest that they know you cannot pay so they can repossess your car when you run out of money and then they just sell the same car again to the next guy. They also have clauses in the contracts allowing them to garnish your paycheck for payments.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had roughly 40K USD in debt from medical bills and expenses that insurance screwed me over on. Had to file chapter 13 and restructure everything. Some was wiped away, some was not.

I'm lucky enough to be solid mid-middle class making around 75k USD a year living in an area were average income is 30k per year. Very white collar, presented well in court and pled my case. I have 2 more years of paying an additional 700 bucks a month till its absolved and then I'm a free man. I wrapped everything together, car, all medical debt, and unsecured debt into the same case. So other than my rent, phone, and utilities, that 700 is my only other expense. (No college debt, no baby mama or kids, currently single)

That being said after taxes, insurance, and 401k, I bring home over $4000 a month as a salary employee, I'm more than able to survive just fine and save plenty with this payment structure. If I made average income I would have filed chapter 7 and been fucked for 10 years. All my extra money goes towards savings with the exception of a small amount of going towards my hobbies, which are modest. I like to camp, it's cheap and easy, most of nature is free around me. Upstate WI, USA.

My advice would work smarter not harder. Obviously work hard, but find something where you make more money than what you do now. If you have no education get into a trade or get a second job. Live modestly and find small things like; gaming, camping, reading, ect that give you big bang for buck. Don't get addicted to anything and don't knock someone up. You'll be free in a couple years if you stick to the payments.

Also, don't file bankruptcy if you can avoid it, even if its one that leaves you less fucked like chapter 13. A bankruptcy filing still costs around 4k USD and the courts are not kind to everyone.

Best of luck Anon
